question: [File: aptos-core/execution/executor-types/src/error.rs] [Error Handling] [Panic vs Error] Are there any code paths where ExecutorError should cause a panic for safety reasons but instead returns an error, potentially allowing continued execution in unsafe states? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/execution/executor-types/src/error.rs] [Error Handling] [Silent Failure] Can ExecutorError instances be silently dropped or ignored in calling code, causing critical failures to go unnoticed? (High)

[File: aptos-core/execution/executor-types/src/error.rs] [Error Handling] [Non-Deterministic Errors] Could different validators generate different ExecutorError variants for the same underlying issue due to timing, causing consensus divergence? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/execution/executor-types/src/error.rs] [Error Handling] [Error Recovery] Does the error type provide enough information for safe recovery, or could automatic recovery from certain errors lead to corrupted state? (High)

[File: aptos-core/execution/executor-types/src/error.rs] [Concurrency] [Thread Safety] Is ExecutorError safe to share across threads during parallel execution, or could race conditions in error handling cause undefined behavior? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/execution/executor-types/src/error.rs] [Concurrency] [Error Ordering] In parallel execution scenarios, if multiple threads generate ExecutorErrors simultaneously, could the order of error handling affect correctness? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/execution/executor-types/src/error.rs] [Integration] [Error Propagation] When ExecutorError is propagated through multiple layers, could important security context be lost, making it impossible to determine if an error was caused by an attack? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/execution/executor-types/src/error.rs] [Integration] [Retry Logic Abuse] Could an attacker trigger specific ExecutorError types that cause automatic retries, amplifying resource consumption and causing denial of service? (High)

[File: aptos-core/execution/executor-types/src/error.rs] [Integration] [Error-Based Probing] Can an attacker systematically trigger different error types to map out the internal state and execution flow of validators? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/execution/executor-types/src/error.rs] [Integration] [State Machine Corruption] If errors occur during critical state transitions, does ExecutorError provide enough information to safely rollback or does it leave the executor in an inconsistent state? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/execution/executor-types/src/error.rs] [Type: HashValue] [Hash Collision] Do the BlockNotFound and DataNotFound variants properly validate that HashValues are cryptographically secure, or could hash collisions allow attackers to cause execution failures? (High)

[File: aptos-core/execution/executor-types/src/error.rs] [Type: HashValue] [Hash Preimage Attack] Could an attacker generate specific HashValues that trigger error paths, allowing them to map the internal structure of block and batch storage? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/execution/executor-types/src/error.rs] [Type: HashValue] [Zero Hash Attack] Are zero or special HashValues properly handled in error variants, or could they cause unexpected behavior or bypass security checks? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/execution/executor-types/src/error.rs] [Type: Version] [Version Arithmetic] In BadNumTxnsToCommit, are all arithmetic operations on Version types checked for overflow/underflow, or could this lead to incorrect transaction counting? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/execution/executor-types/src/error.rs] [Type: Version] [Version Monotonicity] Does the error type enforce that first_version <= target_version, or could version number reversals cause state corruption? (High)

[File: aptos-core/execution/executor-types/src/error.rs] [Type: Version] [Maximum Version] What happens when Version approaches u64::MAX - could this cause wraparound issues in BadNumTxnsToCommit calculations? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/execution/executor-types/src/error.rs] [Error Messages] [Information Leakage] Do error message strings expose internal implementation details that could help attackers understand system architecture or find vulnerabilities? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/execution/executor-types/src/error.rs] [Error Messages] [Log Injection] Can error messages contain user-controlled data that could be used for log injection or log forgery attacks? (Medium)
[File: aptos-core/execution/executor-types/src/error.rs] [Error Messages] [Denial of Service] Could extremely long error messages cause memory or performance issues when logged or transmitted? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/execution/executor-types/src/error.rs] [Derive: PartialEq/Eq] [Comparison Attack] Can the PartialEq implementation be exploited to compare errors in a way that reveals sensitive information about execution state? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/execution/executor-types/src/error.rs] [Derive: PartialEq/Eq] [Timing Side Channel] Does error comparison take constant time, or could timing differences reveal information about error types or contents? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/execution/executor-types/src/error.rs] [Type: ExecutorResult] [Error Handling Pattern] Does the ExecutorResult type alias encourage proper error handling patterns, or could it make it easier to accidentally ignore critical errors? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/execution/executor-types/src/error.rs] [Type: ExecutorResult] [Unwrap Safety] Are there code paths using ExecutorResult where .unwrap() or .expect() could cause panics in production, leading to validator crashes? (High)

[File: aptos-core/execution/executor-types/src/error.rs] [Attack Scenario] [Byzantine Validator] Can a Byzantine validator intentionally trigger specific ExecutorError types to cause honest validators to diverge in their error handling, leading to consensus failure? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/execution/executor-types/src/error.rs] [Attack Scenario] [Transaction Censorship] Could an attacker exploit error handling to prevent specific transactions from being executed while appearing to honestly participate in consensus? (High)
